newsitem.title: USA: U.S. rail traffic up slightly from year ago--AAR.
newsitem.headline: U.S. rail traffic up slightly from year ago--AAR.

text.p: U.S. freight traffic on the nation's major railroads rose 2.8 percent in the latest week compared to a year ago, the Association of American Railroads said Thursday.

The AAR said it estimated total railroad volume in the week ended December 21 at 25.6 billion ton-miles, up from 24.9 billion in the same week last year. A ton-mile equals one ton of freight hauled one mile.

Railroad freight traffic in the latest week included new carloadings of 342,845, a 2.2 percent increase from 335,627 a year ago. Carloadings were up in nine categories from a year ago, down in nine and flat in one.
New traffic in trailers and containers totalled 162,501, up 10.3 percent from 147,354 in the year-ago week.
So far this year, the AAR said trailer and container traffic was up 2.5 percent from the same period last year, carloadings were down 0.4 percent and ton-miles were up 2.0 percent.
